title: Czech Republic - Factors To Watch on Oct 30
text: PRAGUE, Oct 30 (Reuters) - Here are news stories, press reports and events to watch which may affect Czech financial markets on Wednesday. ALL TIMES GMT (Czech Republic: GMT + 1 hour) =========================ECONOMIC DATA========================== Real-time economic data releases.................... Summary of economic data and forecasts........... Recently released economic data.................. Previous stories on Czech data............. **For a schedule of corporate and economic events: http://emea1.apps.cp.thomsonreuters.com/Apps/CountryWeb/#/2E/events-overview ============================NEWS/EVENTS======================== CME: Shares in Central European Media Enterprises (CME) fell sharply in Prague on Tuesday as some investors ditched the stock after AT&T's deal to sell its majority stake to Czech investor PPF missed price expectations. CEE MARKETS: Central European currencies gave up some of their recent gains on Tuesday after a strong run in recent weeks, while in Prague Central European Media Enterprises (CME) CETV.PR shares plunged on disappointment at the price of a acquisition bid. EUROPE POWER: European baseload electricity prices for day-ahead delivery gained on Tuesday, supported by forecasts for a fall in wind power generation and an expected rise in demand. ---------------------- MARKET SNAPSHOT ------------------------ Index/Crown Currency Latest Prev Pct change Pct change close on day in 2019 vs Euro 25.52 25.52 0 0.69 vs Dollar 22.942 22.962 0.09 -2.35 Czech Equities 1,062.18 1,062.18 0.06 7.67 U.S. Equities 27,071.42 27,090.72 -0.07 16.05 Pvs close or current levels vs prior domestic close at 1600 GMT ===========================PRESS DIGEST========================= ENERGY: The Czech Republic covers 37% of its energy consumption by imports, compared to the European Union average of 55%. Hospodarske Noviny, page 2 NUCLEAR: Opponents of new nuclear energy capacity planned in the Czech Republic may use a veridct of the European Union's Court of Justice which pointed out the issue of energy solidarity in the EU when it upheld Poland's complaint against the Opal crude pipeline. A wider interpretation of the solidarity clause may affect all energy sources, including the new blocs planned by the state-controlled CEZ , lawyers said. Hospodarske Noviny, page 16 (Reuters has not verified the stories, nor does it vouch for their accuracy.) Prague Newsroom: +420 224 190 477 E-mail: prague.newsroom@thomsonreuters.com (Reporting by Prague Newsroom)
